title: EEUU retirar√° parte de su personal de Oriente Pr√≥ximo ante las tensiones con Ir√°n - LA NACION
text:
Por Daphne Psaledakis, Idrees Ali, Ahmed Rasheed y Jeff Mason WASHINGTON/BAGDAD, 11 jun (Reuters) - El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, dijo el mi√©rcoles que personal estadounidense estaba siendo trasladado fuera de Oriente Pr√≥ximo porque "podr√≠a ser un lugar peligroso", y a√±adi√≥ que Estados Unidos no permitir√≠a que Ir√°n tenga un arma nuclear. Reuters inform√≥ el mi√©rcoles de que Estados Unidos est√° preparando una evacuaci√≥n parcial de su embajada iraqu√≠ y permitir√° que los dependientes militares abandonen lugares alrededor de Oriente Pr√≥ximo debido a riesgos mayores de seguridad en la regi√≥n, seg√∫n fuentes estadounidenses e iraqu√≠es. Las cuatro fuentes estadounidenses y las dos iraqu√≠es no precisaron qu√© riesgos de seguridad hab√≠an motivado la decisi√≥n, y las informaciones sobre la posible evacuaci√≥n hicieron subir los precios del petr√≥leo m√°s de un 4%. Un responsable estadounidense dijo que el Departamento de Estado hab√≠a autorizado salidas voluntarias de Bar√©in y Kuwait. El Departamento de Estado actualiz√≥ el mi√©rcoles por la noche su aviso de viaje a todo el mundo para reflejar la √∫ltima postura de Estados Unidos. "El 11 de junio, el Departamento de Estado orden√≥ la salida del personal gubernamental estadounidense que no estuviera en situaci√≥n de emergencia debido al aumento de las tensiones en la regi√≥n", dec√≠a la advertencia. La decisi√≥n de Estados Unidos de evacuar a parte del personal llega en un momento vol√°til en la regi√≥n. Los esfuerzos de Trump para alcanzar un acuerdo nuclear con Ir√°n parecen estar estancados y la inteligencia estadounidense indica que Israel ha estado haciendo preparativos para un ataque contra las instalaciones nucleares iran√≠es. "Se los est√° sacando (de la regi√≥n) porque podr√≠a ser un lugar peligroso; veremos qu√© pasa", dijo Trump a los periodistas. "Hemos dado aviso para que se trasladen".
A la pregunta sobre si se puede hacer algo para bajar la temperatura en la regi√≥n, Trump dijo: "No pueden tener un arma nuclear. Muy sencillo, no pueden tener un arma nuclear". Trump ha amenazado repetidamente con atacar Ir√°n si fracasan las titubeantes conversaciones sobre su programa nuclear y, en una entrevista publicada este mismo mi√©rcoles, dijo que cada vez confiaba menos en que Teher√°n accediera a dejar de enriquecer uranio, una exigencia estadounidense clave. El ministro de Defensa iran√≠, Aziz Nasirzadeh, tambi√©n dijo el mi√©rcoles que si Ir√°n era objeto de ataques tomar√≠a represalias atacando bases estadounidenses en la regi√≥n. La embajada de EEUU en Kuwait dijo en un comunicado el mi√©rcoles que no hab√≠a "cambiado su postura de personal" y que segu√≠a estando "plenamente operativa."
PRESENCIA MILITAR Estados Unidos tiene presencia militar en toda la importante regi√≥n productora de petr√≥leo, con bases en Irak, Kuwait, Qatar, Bar√©in y Emiratos √Årabes Unidos.
El secretario de Defensa de Estados Unidos, Pete Hegseth, ha autorizado la salida voluntaria de los militares dependientes de los emplazamientos de Oriente Pr√≥ximo, seg√∫n inform√≥ un responsable estadounidense. Otro cargo estadounidense dijo que esto afectaba sobre todo a los familiares ubicados en Bar√©in, donde se encuentra la mayor parte de ellos. "El Departamento de Estado tiene prevista una salida ordenada para (la) embajada estadounidense en Bagdad. La intenci√≥n es hacerlo por medios comerciales, pero el ej√©rcito estadounidense est√° preparado por si se solicita ayuda", dijo un tercer responsable estadounidense.
La agencia estatal de noticias iraqu√≠ cit√≥ a una fuente gubernamental seg√∫n la cual Bagdad no hab√≠a registrado ninguna indicaci√≥n de seguridad que exigiera una evacuaci√≥n.
(Informaci√≥n de Daphne Psaledakis, Idrees Ali, Humeyra Pamuk, Steve Holland y Jeff Mason en Washington, Michelle Nichols en Nueva York, Ahmed Rasheed y Timour Azhari en Bagdad y Parisa Hafezi en Dub√°i; informaci√≥n adicional de Sam Tabahriti en Londres; redacci√≥n de Jaidaa Taha, Yomna Ehab y Angus McDowall; edici√≥n de Deepa Babington y Stephen Coates; edici√≥n en espa√±ol de Jorge Ollero Castela)

title: List of new property laws for 2024 - changes to holiday lets and more rights for renters
text: Renters are set to be awarded more rights in 2024 as a major new law comes into force. And there could also be good news for areas struggling with soaring numbers of [ holidays lets](https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/property/), as ministers consider fresh rules. Most of 2024 new property rules form part of the government's levelling up programme which aims to improve housing stock and provide a better, fairer balance between the interests of tenants and landlords, reports [ MEN.](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/new-property-laws-coming-force-28329181) Most of these new rules form part of the government's levelling up programme which aims to improve housing stock and provide a better, fairer balance between the interests of tenants and landlords. In November this year, King Charles III delivered the first King's Speech in more than 70 years, with some new property bills announced. Amongst the bills, [King Charles](https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/all-about/king-charles-iii) referred to the two new laws that are set to improve the property market, the Leasehold and Freehold Bill and the Renters (Reform) Bill. He said: "My Ministers will bring forward a bill to reform the housing market by making it cheaper and easier for leaseholders to purchase their freehold and tackling the exploitation of millions of homeowners through punitive service charges. READ MORE [: List of new UK travel rules for 2024 - hand luggage change, daily tourist taxes and new visas](https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/list-new-uk-travel-rules-9000635) [Try BristolLive Premium for FREE with no ads and new features](https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/try-bristollive-premium-free-no-8958271) He added: "Renters will benefit from stronger security of tenure and better value, while landlords will benefit from reforms to provide certainty that they can regain their properties when needed." Renters (Reform) Bill This bill was originally meant to be rolled out in January 2024, but there has been a delay in its third reading. This means it will be introduced later in the year, but it's still good news for renters. It will see the end of a blanket ban on pets, so tenants will have the right to request a pet which landlords cannot unreasonably refuse. The bill will also make it illegal to have blanket bans on renting to tenants in receipt of benefits or with children ‚Äì so no family is discriminated against. The government will also recognise that the student market is largely cyclical and that landlords must be able to guarantee possession each year for a new set of tenants. They will introduce a new ground for possession to facilitate this. And Landlords will also be handed stronger powers to evict anti-social tenants. Those who are persistently disruptive should be evicted ‚Äì a measure that will be welcomed by both landlords and responsible tenants. The Bill will seek to halve the delay between a landlord serving notice for anti-social behaviour and eviction, with landlords able to make a claim in the court immediately. If a tenant breaches their tenancy agreement or damages the property, landlords will be able to evict them in as little as two weeks. The government say they will not commence the abolition of no fault evictions until stronger possession grounds and a new court process is in place. Proposed changes for holiday lets With a housing shortage in the UK, the government now appears to be focussing on short-term lets to balance the lack of housing against the benefits tourism brings. There are currently two new consultations on proposed changes to holiday lets, with the new changes anticipated to come into force in 2024. A registration scheme was available for property owners with holiday lets in England, who were asked to respond to a consultation by June 7, 2023. This was to help build a picture on the number and location of short-term lets to assess the impact on local communities. Proposals also include a new use class for short term lets, the potential for permitted development to change a dwelling to short term let and vice versa and potential flexibility for owners to let out as short term lets for a number of nights only. Responses are also being sought on whether planning would be needed if the number of letting nights is restricted and if so the number of letting nights available. Leasehold and Freehold Bill Currently, if your property is a leasehold, you own the house but not the building or land it sits on, which means you pay ground rent to the freeholder. The new law will see this form of homeownership banned, meaning anyone who buys a new home going forward will own the building as well as the land it sits on. The new Bill is set to improve homeownership for millions of leaseholders in England and Wales by making it cheaper and easier for more leaseholders to extend their lease, buy their freehold, and takeover management of their building. The new laws will increase the standard lease extension term from 90 years to 990 years for both houses and flats, with ground rent reduced to ¬£0. This will ensure that leaseholders can enjoy secure, ground rent free ownership of their properties for years to come, without the hassle and expense of future lease extensions. It will also fully ban the creation of new leasehold houses so that, other than in exceptional circumstances, every new house in England and Wales will be freehold from the outset. The bill will also remove the requirement for a new leaseholder to have owned their house or flat for two years before they can benefit from these changes.

text:

Il momento √® storico per la Scuderia Ferrari. Il Gran Premio dell‚ÄôArabia Saudita, da poco terminato, ha visto Charles Leclerc conquistare il primo podio stagionale, secondo di fila per il team, con la terza posizione alle spalle delle due Red Bull di Max Verstappen e Sergio Perez. Qualla del madrileno non √® stata l‚Äôunica presenta speciale nel paddock. Anche John Elkann, insieme al figlio, √® arrivato al Jeddah Corniche Circuit per supportare la squadra del Cavallino Rampante.
‚Äú√à stata una grandissima gara con il podio, il giro veloce di Leclerc e il debutto del pilota pi√π giovane della storia di Ferrari in F1 con Bearman‚Äù ha dichiarato il presidente della Scuderia ai microfoni di Sky Sport F1. ‚ÄúMa soprattutto un grande spirito di squadra con Carlos Sainz presente ai box nonostante l‚Äôintervento. √à questo che fa sentire Ferrari cos√¨ speciale ed essere tutti quanti noi molo orgogliosi di aver lavorato per un risultato decisamente incoraggiante. ‚ÄúSicuramente se guardiamo a dove eravamo un anno fa, questo campionato parte meglio e, come sempre, l‚Äôimportante √® cercare di progredire, √® questa la dinamica che in questo momento si sente in Ferrari, che va incoraggiata e apprezzata. Per questo ci tengo a condividere come c‚Äô√® un gruppo, un‚Äôorganizzazione, una voglia di fare insieme e permettere al team fare il meglio possibile. Questo oggi era estremamente palpabile‚Äù.
La presenza di Elkann al Gran Premio dell‚ÄôArabia Saudita √® stata anche la primissima occasione per avere delle sue dichiarazioni in merito all‚Äôarrivo di Lewis Hamilton in Ferrari il prossimo anno, un grandissimo colpo di mercato. ‚ÄúNel 2026 si chiuder√† un ciclo per poi aprirne un altro. L‚Äôimportante √® continuare ad essere competitivi ed alimentare questo spirito. Ho sempre detto negli anni anche pubblicamente quanto Lewis Hamilton sia un grandissimo pilota, quanto abba fatto per la Formula 1 e il fatto che lui raggiunger√† la Ferrari √® un segno importate di quanto lui creda di poter fare delle grandi cose con noi. Bearman, ma in realt√† nessuno, avrebbe mai pensato di essere davanti ad Hamilton al debutto, ma neanche Lando Norris. Lo ricorder√† per tutta la vita. L‚Äôabbraccio che Lewis ha dato ad Oliver dimostra ancora una volta quanto lui sia un grande campione anche fuori dalla pista, e soprattutto un esempio per le generazioni che stanno crescendo molto bene‚Äù.

author: PTI
title: Army summit on May 8 to recognize veterans in nation‚Äôs progress - The Hindu BusinessLine
text:
The Indian Army will host a summit next week with the aim of highlighting the capabilities, potential, and skills of military veterans as a driving force in the nation's progress, officials said on Saturday.
Also read: Army takes a slew of organisational and procedural transformation measures The summit, which is being organised by the Army Welfare Placement Organisation (AWPO), will be held on May 8. The event promises to provide a comprehensive understanding of how veterans can serve as an engine of growth for the nation, a senior official said. It will highlight the capabilities, potential, and skills of military veterans as a driving force in the nation's progress.
With the participation of corporate leaders, military veterans, leading industry figures, and veteran entrepreneurs, the summit aims to bridge gaps in training, orientation, and preparation, paving the way for veterans to make significant contributions across diverse sectors of the economy, the army said.
Since its inception in 1999, the AWPO has been instrumental in facilitating the seamless integration of veterans into civilian careers, while upholding the spirit of service and dedication that define the armed forces, it said.
Also read: Army raises specialised technology unit ‚ÄòSTEAG‚Äô for future warfare The AWPO serves as a bridge between the skilled workforce of veterans and the opportunities available in the corporate and public sectors, the officials said.
The summit will be centred around three major themes: harnessing veteran's potential and experience, skills required to meet public and private sector needs and unveiling opportunities for veterans in India's growth story. Discussions have also been planned on many other macro and micro issues concerning the veteran community.
Military veterans represent a profoundly trained, motivated, and exceptionally skilled resource capable of seamlessly transitioning into diverse sectors with minimal orientation, the army said.
Annually, around 60,000 adept and driven soldiers, whose professionalism, leadership, technical, and managerial abilities have been meticulously honed through extensive training, retire from service, it said.
These veterans, at the zenith of their capabilities developed through real-world high-pressure experience and a goal-oriented mindset cultivated over years of service, embody a significant national asset that must be effectively leveraged to propel India's growth story, the army said.
The AWPO empowers veterans for entrepreneurship programmes, government jobs and job opportunities in friendly foreign countries.
It is pertinent to note that the AWPO has shown a 30 per cent increase in its placements during the last two years, the army said.
The bulk placements include 3,000 in the Indian Railways, 1,200 in dedicated freight corridors and approximately 3,200 as drivers for the Bihar Police, which is still under progress, it said.
Some have also been placed with the Port Trust in Kolkata and Kandla ports, and as observers with the National Testing Agency.
In its latest drive, the AWPO, as a pilot project, has been able to place 10 veterans with All Nippon Airways. They have been employed in Japan since March of this year.
In entrepreneurship programmes, approximately 900 veterans have been empowered in various fields, it added.

author: Greg Jaffe
title: Can the exhausted, angry people of Ottawa County learn to live together?
text:
West Olive, Mich. - All year, the new conservative Christian majority on the Ottawa County Board of Commissioners had been searching for a way to get rid of Adeline Hambley, who ran the west Michigan county‚Äôs health department. It wasn‚Äôt as easy as it seemed. They had discussed firing Hambley, whom they saw as an instrument of government tyranny. But her job came with protections, written into state law, that were intended to insulate her from political influence or retribution.
They had proposed paying Hambley $4 million to leave. She accepted in early November. But the commissioners backed out a few days later when they learned that the payment could damage the county‚Äôs bond rating and tank its finances.
Now it was Nov. 14.The commissioners huddled with their lawyers in a windowless conference room at the county‚Äôs boxy, brick government complex. Hambley and her lawyer waited anxiously in a small room just down the hall. The two sides were stuck.
All over the country, deep partisan divisions were making it harder for American government to function and its citizens to coexist. The number of intractable disputes seemed to grow by the day: climate change, racial equity, gender-affirming care, guns, immigration, abortion. The battles were paralyzing Congress and pitting red and blue states against each other.Increasingly, they were consuming school boards and local government.
In Ottawa County, a fast-growing community of 300,000 along Lake Michigan, the nexus for so many of these ideological fights was the health department.
The hard-right Republicans on the 11-person county board swept into office last year after defeating more-moderate GOP incumbents in a primary. The old commissioners had for years focused on keeping taxes low and the county‚Äôs biggest multinational employers happy. Their replacements reflected an increasingly populist and conspiratorial GOP - remade in the image of Donald Trump.
They complained that they couldn‚Äôt trust Hambley. They accused her of supporting mask mandates and pushing coronavirus vaccines that they believed were unproven and possibly unsafe. They said her employees had encouraged dangerous, sexually perverse behavior by attending a local Pride festival, where they tested attendees for sexually transmitted diseases and administered the mpox vaccine.
Hambley insisted that her job wasn‚Äôt to serve the board. It was her responsibility to look after the health and safety of all of the county‚Äôs residents, regardless of their moral or political beliefs. ‚ÄúI want to work with the commissioners so we can protect the community,‚Äù said the 44-year-old, who had sued the county to keep her position. ‚ÄúBut I am not their subordinate.‚Äù
Their latest, fruitless negotiating session was approaching the seven-hour mark on Nov. 14 when Doug Zylstra, the lone Democrat on the board and a strong backer of Hambley, suggested an option that only a few days earlier would have seemed unthinkable.
What if Hambley and the conservatives on the board tried to negotiate a temporary truce? No one was completely comfortable with the idea, but none of the commissioners rejected it. After a half-hour of talks, the commissioners had cobbled together a bare-bones proposal that would allow Hambley to keep her job and pay her about $100,000 to cover her legal fees.
Zylstra sensed that Hambley would not accept it. She wanted the commissioners to acknowledge her independence and authority as county health officer. She needed guarantees that they wouldn‚Äôt bully her staff or simply try to fire her again in a few weeks.
Still, Zylstra saw the board‚Äôs offer as a small step forward - a rare glimmer of hope in an otherwise depressing and divisive year for the board and the county. The stalemate was finally forcing the two sides to wrestle with a question that for 11 months they had been unwilling to even consider: Amid all the rancor, could they somehowfigure out a way to live together?
Paying a premium The driving force behind the year-long effort to remove Hambley was Joe Moss, a 38-year-old newcomer to politics and the board chair.
Moss rarely talked about the actual work of county government: repairing roads, maintaining parks, inspecting restaurants and collecting taxes. Instead his public statements and social media posts described an epochal battle between Christian conservatives and powerful secular forces in the media, academia, government and the medical establishment that he said were trying to outlaw his faith and seize control of his community.
‚ÄúCensorship, demonization and public intimidation of Conservatives have been the go-to method to obtain submission and silence,‚Äù Moss wrote in the midst of the board‚Äôs standoff with Hambley and the health department.
A few days later, he shared a post that said: ‚ÄúProgressives are working hard to make unapologetic conservative Christianity unacceptable in the public life of our nation.‚Äù
‚ÄúThis is absolutely true,‚Äù he added.
Moss‚Äôs posts echoed the messages he and his constituents were hearing regularly from their pastors on Sunday. And they mirrored the increasingly angry and apocalyptic rhetoric of national Republican leaders like Trump, who described his political enemies as ‚Äúvermin,‚Äù often training his ire on the federal bureaucracy and its institutions.
‚ÄúEither the deep state destroys America or we destroy the deep state,‚Äù the former president said.
In Ottawa County, Moss‚Äôs battle began with the 100-person health department. Hours after taking office on Jan. 3, Moss and his allies on the board voted to demote Hambley and replace her with Nate Kelly, a safety manager at a local HVAC company who had gained prominence as a vaccine skeptic and critic of mask mandates.
The previous Republican-dominated board had appointed Hambley to her position in December 2022 after a months-long, nationwide search. They saw Hambley as a long-serving, reliable county employee.To Moss, she was a cog in a vast and unelected bureaucracy that included the World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.
Moss declined to comment for this article but discussed the department‚Äôs importance in an interview with a local right-wing talk-radio host. ‚ÄúIn many ways, public health has been weaponized in the United States and outside the country,‚Äù Moss told him. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why we need people who are going to prioritize freedom and the Constitution. ‚Ä¶ We should not have top-down governmental control making daily decisions for hundreds of thousands or millions of people.‚Äù
Hambley sued the board in February to stop the conservative commissioners from demoting or replacing her. So Moss looked for other ways of limiting her and the department‚Äôs power. In late August, Moss and the county administrator gave Hambley less than three days to slash the department‚Äôs proposed 2024 budget in half, from$17.4 million to $9 million. The order came despite the county‚Äôs growing tax revenue and flush coffers. Hambley said she tried to comply but quickly concluded it was not feasible.
In news releases and public statements, she warned that the cuts would damage the county‚Äôs economy, endanger public safety and trigger a state takeover of the department. Moss and the board gradually backed off their most extreme demands. In late September, the commissioners authorized the department to spend $14.4 million in 2024, down about 20 percent from the previous year‚Äôs spending. On the night the budget passed, Moss accused Hambley of ‚Äúinciting fear and panic in the community‚Äù with her warnings and initiated the formal process to fire her.
State law required the board to prove in a public hearing that Hambley was ‚Äúincompetent‚Äù or had committed malfeasance. Current and former county employees testified over two days in late October about the chaotic budget process and the growing political pressure on county workers. When the hearing was done, the county‚Äôs lawyers warned the commissioners that voting to fire Hambley carried risks. A judge could order the county to reinstate her and pay damages.
Moss and his allies on the board debated their options for several days before the two sides reconvened on Nov. 6 at the county government center. They first offered Hambley $1.8 million to leave and drop her lawsuit. Hambley and her attorney countered with $8 million, according to court documents. The back-and-forth negotiations continued for several hours. Near the end of the day, Hambley and her lawyer said she would take $4.45 million to leave, though she didn‚Äôt expect the board to accept.
The county‚Äôs lawyers advised thecommissioners that the proposed settlement was on the high end of what she might receive if she prevailed at trial. Hambley‚Äôs annual salary and benefits amounted to about $180,000. Several commissioners, who wanted to keep Hambley in the job, argued that the offer was exorbitant and unnecessary. A majority of the commissioners, though, wanted her gone.
The final decision on the proposed settlement fell to Moss. He had been saying for months that the nation‚Äôs survival required ‚Äúunapologetic‚Äù conservative leaders with ‚Äúspines of steel.‚Äù Now the moment had arrived for him to show he was that kind of leader.
Moss told the attorneys that he was ‚Äúwilling to pay a premium‚Äù to guarantee Hambley‚Äôs departure, according to several people in the room. Sylvia Rhodea, the board‚Äôs vice chair, suggested one last counter of $4 million. Moss agreed. Soon the lawyers were walking the offer down the hall, where Hambley and her attorney were waiting.
A broken deal Hambley had gone to the county government complex on the morning of Nov. 6 expecting that she would spend the day fighting to keep her job. She wasn‚Äôt sure what to do when she saw the board‚Äôs $4 million counteroffer.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to feel like I‚Äôm selling my soul in some way,‚Äù she texted her husband.
The daughter of a machinist and a school bus driver, Hambley was the first in her family to graduate from college. She had started with the county two decades earlier as a restaurant and septic inspector, working her way up to the department‚Äôs top job while raising three children, now 19, 17 and 12. That day, her husband was at their home - a small, muddy farm with chickens, goats and a pig named Waffles, who weighed several hundred pounds and slept in their front entryway.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs life changing for our family,‚Äù she texted him. ‚ÄúWhat do you want me to do?‚Äù He told her to listen to her lawyer.
Hambley accepted the proposed settlement and the lawyers began working to finalize the language so that the commissioners could reconvene in a week and vote publicly on it.
A few days later, the deal fell apart. The county‚Äôs lawyers told the board that the large payout could cause its insurer to drop the county‚Äôs coverage, according to several commissioners who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal discussions. The county, in turn, could lose its AAA bond rating, driving up the costs that it, along with schools and townships throughout Ottawa, would incur to borrow money.
The county‚Äôs lawyers emailed Hambley‚Äôs attorney on Nov. 10 to say they had ‚Äúrun into problems‚Äù with the settlement.
On Nov. 14, everyone returned to the government center for another day of haggling. The board offered Hambley $1 million to quit, the maximum its lawyers said the county could give her without putting its bond ratingat risk. Hambley rejected it. The boardfloated Zylstra‚Äôs idea of atruce, in which the board would paysome of Hambley‚Äôs legal fees. She would drop her lawsuit and stay in the job without any protections. She turned down that proposal as well.
About 4 p.m.,the talks ended for the day. Hambley headed to the health department to address her employees - nurses, social workers, health inspectors and epidemiologists - who had packed the office‚Äôs main conference room. Many were wearing T-shirts bearing the slogan ‚ÄúNevertheless, she persisted,‚Äù in support of their boss.
To Moss and his supporters, Hambley was the vanguard of a national movement that was seeking to marginalize and silence Christian conservatives. To employees at the health department, she was their shield. She was fighting not just for them, but for embattled medical professionals across the state and the country. The Holland Sentinel, the local newspaper, had published the details of the $4 million deal a few days earlier,before it had been withdrawn. For the workers in the room, the news that Hambley was willing to take money to leavewas a gut punch; some said they had felt abandoned and betrayed.
Hambley told her employees that she had wanted to stay and fight. ‚ÄúI would love to keep being the county health officer,‚Äù she said. But a majority of the commissioners were determined to get rid of her.
If the board fired her, Hambley told her staff, she probably would have to fight for a year or longer in court before she could return to her job. Even if she prevailed, there were no guarantees that a judge would order the board to reinstate her.
Hambley and Marcia Mansaray, her deputy, described the proposed $4 million settlement as a powerful deterrent that would clarify state law and send a message to other county commissions in Michigan thatremoving a health officer carried huge costs.
The employees began to ask questions. They wanted to know who would protect them if both Hambley and Mansaray were gone. Hambley replied that Gwen Unzicker, a physician who served as the department‚Äôs medical director, would fight to make sure their work met the standards of care.
They asked Hambley what she was hearing from the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, which also had oversight responsibilities for the department. Initially, state officials had pressed Hambley to try to ‚Äúfind common ground‚Äù with the new commissioners. Lately, the response from state officials had been silence, she told the workers.
They asked about the HVAC safety manager whom the board hoped to put in charge of the department if Hambley departed. There wasn‚Äôt much she could tell them.
The hour-long session was nearing its end. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine what you‚Äôre feeling right now,‚Äù an employee in the medical examiner‚Äôs office told Hambley. ‚ÄúThank you for being willing to fight for us.‚Äù Hambley and Mansaray thanked their employees for their perseverance and tenacity. The room burst into applause that lasted for a couple of minutes.
When the cheering died down, the workers headed home. They described their state of mind in interviews as ‚Äúanxious,‚Äù ‚Äúuncertain,‚Äù ‚Äústressed‚Äù and ‚Äúutterly exhausted.‚Äù Most doubted that Moss or his allies on the board would be willing to seekan acceptable compromise. Eventually, they would find a way to force Hambley out.
‚ÄúTo them the stakes are eternal,‚Äù Unzicker said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no middle ground. They seem to think what we‚Äôre doing is evil.‚Äù
The fallout grows News of the scuttled $4 million settlement spread quickly through the county. A few hours after Hambley had addressed her staff, the Ottawa County Patriots held apreviously scheduled seminar at a local church. It was titled: ‚ÄúThe Second Amendment: Under Attack and Fighting Back!‚Äù
Rebekah Curran, one of the new commissioners who had taken office in January, sat in the third pew from the front. When the presentation ended, several attendees circled around her, expressing shock that the county would offer Hambley so much money.
‚ÄúAre they actually going to give her $4 million?‚Äù asked an older man who wore a Navy veteran cap and balanced on a cane.
‚ÄúIf you give into one of them, you open the floodgates to them all!‚Äù warned a woman with an American flag scarf draped around her neck.
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe numbers like that were even contemplated,‚Äù said a lawyer in a crisp Oxford shirt and khakis.
Curran told them she didn‚Äôt support the settlement andhad planned to vote against it before it fell apart. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt agree with it!‚Äù she said.
The board had spent more than 30 hours in open and closed session discussing what to do and seemed to have no workable answers. One of the commissioners resigned amid the standoff, citing ‚Äúchanges in his personal and professional life.‚Äù Six of the remaining 10 wanted to remove Hambley. Three were trying to find a way to keep her. Curran was somewhere in the middle. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so tired of the political games on both sides,‚Äù she said.
The battle was affecting the health department‚Äôs ability to keep staff and deliver services. Since the beginning of the year, 24 employees - about a fifth of its workforce - had retired or left for other jobs, according to health department officials. In the five years before the pandemic, the department had averaged about eight departures a year.
One of those who quit in November was Matthew Allen, a supervisor in the department‚Äôs environmental division. He‚Äôd been with the county for 14 years and described himself as a devout Christian who home-schooled his children, voted for Trump and never got a coronavirus vaccine. ‚ÄúNone of that mattered to [Hambley],‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe was a wonderful leader.‚Äù
Allen said Moss‚Äôs interference had led him to leave the county for a state job. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a line between government and religion, and when they get mixed up, you don‚Äôt get people making decisions for the good of the whole,‚Äù he said.
His and other departures from the environmental division were taking a toll, health department officials said. The wait time for septic inspections in the county had tripled since January to 30 days.
The turmoil had also upended Ottawa Food, a health department program that helped feed 22,000 low-income residents each year. The board in the fall had eliminated funding for the program‚Äôs director, a health department employee who coordinated food assistance with 45 local nonprofits and food pantries.In November, amid the fight over Hambley‚Äôs fate, the nonprofits that made up Ottawa Food‚Äôs board announced they were suspending a program that provided aid to seniors and an initiative that supplied churches and food pantries with thousands of pounds of fresh produce.
Rhodea, the board‚Äôs vice chair, accused the health department and its nonprofit partners of playing a ‚Äúpolitical game‚Äù with the program to discredit the commissioners. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre committed to food security in this county,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbut we‚Äôre not committed to dysfunction.‚Äù
The nonprofits on the Ottawa Food board received nearly $1 million from the county in 2023 to run food programs and assist farmers. At a board meeting in late November, Rhodea threatened to take some of that money and start a new county agency that would work more cooperatively with the commissioners. She didn‚Äôt explain how the new agency would operate, but she did have a name for it: ‚ÄúThe Department of Family Impact.‚Äù
Moss, seated next to her, listened and nodded. ‚ÄúA Department of Family Impact sounds really good,‚Äù he mused.
Stirrings of hope The two weeks since Zylstra first raised the possibility of a truce had been turbulent for Hambley, the board and the entire county.
In late November, the 57-year-old Democrat called Hambley to discuss a matter related to the fight over the health department budget and the Ottawa Food program. After a few minutes, the conversation shifted to the negotiations with the board over her future.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling hopeful,‚Äù he told Hambley.
‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Hambley replied. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs there to be hopeful about?‚Äù
Zylstra understood her pessimism. There had been stretches in the summer and fall when he‚Äôd felt he couldn‚Äôt talk to Moss and the other conservatives on the board outside their regular meetings.He worried that they might take his words out of context and use them against him. The strains, he said, mirrored the county as a whole, which he described as ‚Äúbroken‚Äù before pausing to reconsider. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to say that,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre separated into parts.‚Äù The tensionhad also spread to his relationship with his sisters, who were strong supporters of Moss and his movement.
Yet Zylstra also believed there were reasons for optimism: The intervention by the courts had so far dissuaded the board from firing Hambley; hundreds of citizens had rallied to support her and the health department.
Shortly after the $4 million settlement collapsed, Hambley‚Äôs attorney, Sarah Howard, filed a motion asking a state circuit court judge to enforce it, arguing that the two sides had reached agreement on the ‚Äúessential‚Äù terms before the commissioners decided to back out. The board‚Äôs lawyers countered that the deal hadn‚Äôt been finalized and that the commissioners hadn‚Äôt voted publicly to accept it. Both steps were required by law before the settlement was complete, they said.
Judge Jenny L. McNeill, who had been dealing with the case for much of the year, scheduled a Jan. 19 hearing on the matter. In the interim, she urged the two sides to meet with a mediator and try to reach a deal.
‚ÄúI think everyone - not just the parties, but the entire county - needs some resolution here,‚Äù she said.
Zylstra understood that the mistrust and anger in the county weren‚Äôt going to be resolved by mediation or even the courts. The divisions were real and deep.
Like many in Trump‚Äôs Republican Party, Moss framed politics as a battle between good and evil. The nation‚Äôs survival was at stake.Compromise was a sign of weakness and corruption. His perspective had inflamed passions across the county and upended the way the board operated. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt talk about whether we should plow the snow once or twice a day,‚Äù Zylstra said. ‚ÄúThose are not our fights. Our fights are much larger.‚Äù
But the past year and the standoff with Hambley had made it clear that there were limits to the board‚Äôs power, limits that even Moss was being forced to acknowledge.
Zylstra thought that the court-imposed delay might allow emotions to cool. He believed that eventually the board and Hambley would be forced to recognize that their only viable option was coexistence. ‚ÄúAn uneasy truce,‚Äù Zylstra called it.
A trying year was drawing to a close. This was Zylstra‚Äôs hope for the next one.
- - -
Patrick Marley contributed to this report.
